Fig. 1 High angle XRD patterns of (a) MgO catalyst and (b) Ni3C catalyst. Fig 1 Fig. 2 High angle XRD pattern of (a) MgO, (b) Ni3C, (c) MgO/Ni3C (2:1), (d) MgO/Ni3C (1:1), and (e) MgO/Ni3C (1:2) catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 a) Py-FT-IR spectra of the catalysts, b) N2-adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Thermogravimetric analysis of the catalysts. Fig 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst (a) survey spectrum, (b) Nickel, (c) Magnesium, (d) Oxygen and (e) Carbon. Fig 5 Fig. 6 a) SEM image of MgO/Ni3C (1:1), b) EDAX spectrum MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst, c-e) Elemental mapping of Ni, Mg, O, and C. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Effects of reaction temperature on glycerol conversion using different catalysts (Reaction conditions–180 °C - 240 °C, 4 h, 0.1 g of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). Fig 7 Fig. 8 Glycerol conversion and selectivity of ethylene glycol, 1, 2-propanediol, hydroxyacetone, and others (ethanol and methanol) using different catalysts (Reaction conditions–220 °C, 4 h, 0.1 g of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). Fig 8 Fig. 9 a) Effects of catalyst loading on the glycerol conversion and selectivity, b) Effects of reaction time on the glycerol conversion, selectivity, and yield of 1, 2-propanediol c) Regeneration of the washed calcined and unwashed uncalcined catalyst for the glycerol conversion (Reaction conditions–220 °C, 4 h, 0.1 g of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). Fig 9 Fig. 10 Recovery of liquid, gas, and char on glycerol conversion to 1,2-propanediol (Reaction condition–220 °C, 4 h, 0.1 g of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). Laboratory of Advanced Materials Chemistry Advanced Institute of Materials Science Ton Duc Thang University Ho Chi Minh City 758307 Vietnam In this study, the fabrication of MgO, Ni3C and MgO/Ni3C (1:1, 1:2, & 2:1) catalysts via a one-step solid-state synthesis and the production of 1, 2-propanediol from glycerol (a by-product of the biodiesel industry) on the synthesized catalysts without using any external hydrogen sources were presented. Different physicochemical techniques were used to analyze the synthesized catalysts. The XRD result revealed formation of the composites with MgO/Ni3C pure phase catalyst; 5% amorphous and 95% crystalline nature. The MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a high surface area and pore volume of about 183 m2 g −1 and 0.18 cm3 g −1, respectively. MgO/Ni3C (1:1) showed a superior thermal stability and has a stable regeneration. Catalytic conversion of glycerol to 1, 2-propanediol was investigated under different reaction conditions (180 °C -240 °C, 1–5 h, 25–125 mg of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). Compared to other prepared materials, the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a superior activity with about 74% of glycerol conversion, 67% of 1, 2-propanediol selectivity, and about 94% of the total product recovery. Its SRR and TOF values were determined as 15.03×10−3 mol g−1 s−1 and 3.01 s−1, respectively. The results demonstrated that MgO/Ni3C (1:1) is a potential candidate for a superior glycerol conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol conversion Catalysts Magnesium Nickel 1, 2-propanediol 1 Introduction Vegetable oils can be classified into two types, namely edible and non-edible oils [1,2]. Thus, there is an essential perspective to produce biofuels from non-edible oil resources derived from seeds and plants. Furthermore, biofuels can be considered as alternative fuels and environmental pollution-free fuels [3]. All types of bio-oils have a majority of triglyceride-based fatty acids [4–6]. Catalytic conversion of non-edible oils into biodiesel and glycerol (a by-product) is massive and may be used for different starting materials. After the conversion, glycerol is a remarkable by-product of vegetable oils and is produced for every tons of biofuel [2,7]. Glycerol can be converted into value-added products, which has been studied in several reports. Glycerol has been used as a top-twelve building block of chemicals used in cosmetics, food, and medical applications. One of the promising methods to utilize glycerol has been introduced for fine chemical products via catalytic reactions. Significantly, this method has been performed in the presence of hydrogen gas, leading to increase the method's overall cost. However, the same route using bifunctional catalysts will minimize the additional cost. The fine chemical synthesis from a renewable glycerol feedstock using a catalytic reaction at 250 °C under 3.5 MPa of H2 pressure is really expensive [8]. In this synthesis, the hydrogen pressure is essential to produce value-added products such as ethylene diol, 1, 2-propanediol, hydroxyacetone, and other products from glycerol [2,9]. The significant challenge is the external hydrogen gas supply for the aqueous phase reaction [10]. Based on the previous reports, external sources such as 2-propanol and formic acid have been used as hydrogen donors in hydrogenation reactions [9,11]. Additionally, hydrogen donors were also used in glycerol deoxygenation reactions to form hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reactions [12]. Although the utilization of hydrogen sources can avoid secondary reactions, it may increase the production cost. Therefore, we take this challenge into account to avoid using the external sources of hydrogen. The glycerol conversion into 1,2-propanediol is beneficial for different applications such as unsaturated polyester resins, foods, cosmetics, medicine, detergents, paints, and so on [13,14]. Ethylene diol is essential for antifreezes, solvents, and polyester fibers for bulk chemical syntheses. Other essential compounds such as hydroxyacetone were used in various fields such as food industry, cosmetics, textile and so on [13,15]. Previously, noble metals such as Rh, Pt, and Re catalysts were used for glycerol conversion on a large scale (for industrial purposes) [14,16]. However, these noble metals have some drawbacks, such as being costly, having defaults on catalysts regeneration, and requiring high pressure (2 MPa - 10 MPa) and temperature (250 °C - 400 °C) [17]. The drawbacks, as mentioned earlier, can be rectified by replacing noble metals with transition metals such as Ni, Cu, Fe, and Mo, which have been identified as active metals with the aid of Mg acting as a promoter for industrial requirements [2,18]. Therefore, Ni, Cu, and Fe with Mg over Al-supported catalysts have been recently reported for glycerol conversion [12,19-21]. Particularly, Ni-Mg catalysts in metal oxides were not stable and easily leached out during the large-scale application [22]. Using a carbide form could improve the stability and surface acid sites and avoid these issues. Based on the literature, Ni-Al-Fe-based catalysts have been used for glycerol conversion into 1,2-propanediol with the formation of in-situ hydrogen [23,24]. The high glycerol conversion of 93.8% and 1,2-propanediol selectivity of 51.5% have been attained on Pt/Fe2O3(58)-Al2O3 at 250 °C under 35 bar N2 pressure [25]. Therefore, the effect of catalyst support's chemical composition has been tested on different combinations of Ni and Al2O3, MgO, and Al2O3−MgO mixed oxide catalysts for the production of hydrogen gas under aqueous phase reforming conditions in a continuous flow reactor [26–28]. The glycerol conversion was reported under the following reaction conditions: 10 wt% glycerol and 2.5 h−1 of weight hourly space velocity at 250 °C under 5 MPa hydrogen pressure. Under those reaction conditions, the maximum 95% of glycerol conversion and 76% of hydrogen selectivity could be achieved using a 5 wt.% Ni/Al2Mg1 catalyst [26]. Synthesize a bifunctional catalyst (acidic and basic nature) with a highly stable Ni3C based catalyst by a single-step thermal synthesis. The bifunctional nature of catalysts using Ni, Mg based catalyst with 10%Ni/10%MgO/ZrO2 showed the glycerol conversion of about 67.8% and 48.8% of total selectivity was achieved due to bifunctional nature (acidic and basic) [29]. Therefore, the combination of Ni-MgO-based catalyst with a Ni/Mg ratio of 3:7 exhibited the superior activity of glycerol hydrogenolysis with about 67.8% conversion and 80.8% total selectivity of ethylene glycol, 1,2-propylene glycol and glycerol [30]. Glycerol conversion into value-added products has been studied on Mg and Ni-based catalysts. Researchers have developed one-step syntheses of catalysts using a solid-state thermal method. In this study, we mainly focused on a one-step solvent-free material synthesis of MgO/Ni3C catalysts with different molar ratios of MgO and Ni3C by using nickel acetate and magnesium acetylacetonate as respective precursors. It was an essential part of introducing carbide form into the materials. This method was easy to handle, cost-effective, appropriate for large-scale production. It also enhanced the chemical stability, hydrogen spillover, surface acidic and basic sites, and prevent metal leaching. Interestingly, the acidity and basicity of the catalyst played a vital role in the conversion of glycerol, a common feedstock, to produce 1, 2-propanediol without using any external hydrogen sources. 2 Materials and methods Nickel (II) acetate (98%), 1, 2-propanediol (99.5%) and magnesium acetylacetonate (98%) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Hydroxyacetone (95%) and glycerol (99.5%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. 1-butanol was purchased from MolyChem. Ethylene glycol 99% was purchased from SD fine chemicals. Solvents such as methanol, ethanol, acetone, and others were procured and used without further treatments. 2.1 Preparation of MgO/Ni3C composites Ni3C & MgO and bimetallic composites of MgO/Ni3C with different molar ratios of 1:1, 1:2, and 2:1 were fabricated by the solid-state thermal method. The nickel acetate and magnesium acetylacetonate were used as Ni, Mg, O, and C precursors. In the synthesis of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) composite, a mixture of 2.48 g of nickel acetate and 5.16 g of magnesium acetylacetonate sources was completely ground into powders using a ball milling for 1 h. The sample was further transferred into an aluminum boat (10 g in capacity), kept in the center of an entirely closed two-side-packed tubular furnace under N2 atmosphere (50 mL.min−1 controlled by a mass flow controller (MFC)) to eliminate the atm air to avoid the formation of oxide phases. The furnace was subsequently heated at 400 °C (the heating rate: 2 °C per minute) for 3 h under N2 atmosphere (50 mL min−1). The mono-metal MgO & Ni3C and bimetal MgO/Ni3C composite materials with different molar ratios (1:1, 1:2, and 2:1) were obtained using the same procedure with different amounts of the precursors. 2.2 Catalytic activation and reactor set-up Glycerol conversion was conducted in a benchtop stainless steel autoclave reactor with a capacity of 100 mL. Typical catalyst amounts (25 to 125 mg) were activated or reduced by H2 flow through the reactor at 300 ± 2 °C and 0.1 MPa for 3 h. Then, a certain amount of substrate (glycerol 10 wt.% in water) was added to the reactor. The inert atmosphere was maintained by purging an N2 gas four times to ensure no remaining O2 gas. The catalytic activity was investigated over the temperature range of 180 °C - 240 °C, with constant stirring at 600 rpm. Each experimental run was performed in triplicate to ensure accuracy. The conversion and product distribution of liquid samples were analyzed using a Shimadzu GC system with an A D5 capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.5 μm) and an FID detector. 1-butanol is used as an internal standard. Meanwhile, the gas sample analysis was carried out on an Agilent GC coupling with a thermal conductivity detector. 2.3 Data analysis The X conversion of glycerol (%) was calculated by the following equation and obtained from GC results [31]. (1) X = Moles of glycerol transformed Moles of glycerol feed × 100 % The following equation was used to calculate the selectivity (S), (2) S = Moles of product i Moles of glycerol converted × 100 % The yield (Y) was calculated by the following equation, (3) Y = Conversion ( X ) × Selectivity of product i ( S ) × 100 % The specific reaction rate (SRR, mol g−1 s−1) was calculated using the following equation, (4) SRR = F 0 X / w Where, F0 = flow rate of glycerol (mol s−1), X=% of glycerol conversion, and w = catalyst weight (g) [32]. TOF was calculated using the following equation (5) TOF ( s − 1 ) = SRR ( mol g − 1 s − 1 ) Quantity of active sites × 100 % Where the quantity of active sites is calculated from H2 chemisorption (μmol g−1). 2.3 Instrumentation The physicochemical characterization of synthesized materials was tested using different instruments: XRD, BET, TGA, SEM coupling with an EDAX for elemental mapping, and FT-IR, which had been discussed in details in our previous publications [33,34]. Moreover, X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometry was also carried out on a Rigaku Primini analyzer. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images were recorded using a TECNAI-G2 (model T-30) S-twin HRTEM with a field emission gun operating at 300 kV. CHNS-O elemental analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Flash 2000) was used to measure the elemental composition before and after the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis The XRD pattern of MgO (Fig. 1 a) showed broad peaks at 37.2° (111), 43.4° (200), 62.3° (220), 74.6° (311), and 78.7° (222). These plans were well matched with MgO (JCPDS 89–7746) [35,36]. No carbide peak but oxide peaks appeared in the pattern. Fig. 1b displayed the strong and sharp diffraction peaks at 39.3° (110), 41.8° (006), 44.6° (113), 58.7° (116), 71° (300), and 78.10° (119). These plans were well matched with Ni3C (JCPDS 4–850) [37,38]. In addition, Ni pure metallic plans (JCPDS No.: 44–0850) were observed at the diffraction peaks at 44.5° (111), 51.9° (200), and 76.5° (220), as shown in Fig. 1b. The XRD patterns of three different molar ratios of MgO/Ni3C composites prepared via the solid-state synthesis were examined to check the crystallinity of the materials. Fig. 2 showed the new XRD patterns with different diffraction peak intensities. Compared to MgO and Ni3C catalysts (Fig. 2a & b), all the bimetallic MgO/Ni3C composites showed similar diffraction peaks with different intensities (Fig. 2c-e). As shown in Fig. 2c, there were no additional impurity plans of MgO/Ni3C (2:1) composite, indicating the formation of pure phases. The diffraction peaks were slightly shifted towards higher angles, probably due to the oxide phase formation. As shown in Fig. 2d, the XRD pattern of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) composite significantly exhibited plans of MgO peaks. The compressed Ni3C peaks were due to high reactive sites of MgO. Meanwhile, the MgO/Ni3C (1:2) composite's XRD diffraction plans (Fig. 2e) revealed that Ni3C had predominant peaks against compressed peaks of MgO. Overall, XRD results confirmed the formation of Ni in the carbide phase and Mg in the oxide phase. 3.2 Py-FT-IR study The strength and types of Lewis (L) or Bronsted (B) acid sites were examined on MgO, Ni3C, MgO/Ni3C(1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), and MgO/Ni3C (2:1) catalysts by pyridine-Fourier transform infrared (Py-FT-IR) spectra, and the results were shown in Fig. 3 a. Py-FT-IR showed the absorption bands at 1445 cm−1 and 1540 cm−1, matched with L and B acid sites [39]. Moreover, MgO, Ni3C, MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), and MgO/Ni3C (2:1) catalysts showed the absorption bands at 1449 cm−1, 1490 cm−1, 1600–1630 cm−1, and 1645 cm−1. The first broad absorption peaks observed at 1449 cm−1 and 1600–1630 cm−1 were allocated to the L acid sites, while the peak at 1490 cm−1 belonged to both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, and a Py-FT-IR absorbed broad peak at 1645 cm−1 was matched to the B acid site. The Ni3C has shown the major Lewis and Bronsted acid sites. The MgO exhibited the minor acid sites because of the highly basic nature of the catalyst. In the case of composites, MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), and MgO/Ni3C (1:2) catalysts exhibited both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, which would favor the glycerol conversion. Among the composite materials, the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) was more acidic than MgO, Ni3C, MgO/Ni3C (1:2), and MgO/Ni3C (2:1) due to the presence of highly active H + on the Ni3C surface. The composite material MgO/Ni3C (1:1) predominantly produced the essential strength of the acid sites. The Bronsted acid sites were of the following order: MgO/Ni3C (1:1) > Ni3C > MgO/Ni3C (2:1) > MgO/Ni3C (1:2) > MgO. 3.3 N2-sorption study BET isotherms and pore size distribution of MgO, Ni3C, and MgO/Ni3C catalysts were determined to study their textual properties. As shown in Fig. 3b, MgO, Ni3C, and MgO/Ni3C catalysts had type-II isotherms with a mesoporous nature [33,40]. Furthermore, the N2 uptake of the MgO, Ni3C and MgO/Ni3C catalysts measured at a relative pressure (P/P0) of ∼ 0.8 - 0.99 resulted in an H1-type hysteresis loop. The different mesoporous catalysts were subject to determine the surface area and pore volume of the materials. For example, the surface area and pore volume of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst were determined as 183 m2 g−1 and 0.18 cm3 g−1, respectively. Similarly, other materials were examined the textual properties of MgO/Ni3C (2:1) and MgO/Ni3C (1:2) catalysts and data are given in Table 1 . The unit cell parameters were also calculated and presented in Table 1. The textural properties of catalysts were determined using the N2 sorption study. Additionally, the Mg/Ni ratios and C wt.% of the catalysts were determined by XRF and CHNS-O analysis, and the calculated values were displayed in Table 1. Interestingly, the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst had 5.6 wt.% of carbide as compared to other catalysts. 3.4 Thermogravimetric analysis The thermal stability of the prepared catalysts such as MgO/Ni3C (1:1, 1:2 and 2:1) and Mg-Ni-AA (AA means acetylacetonate and acetate) composites was studied by TGA with a recorded temperature range of 40 °C to 700 °C (a heating rate of 8 °C/min) [41]. The Mg-Ni AA composite with three different weight losses occurred: the first weight loss (about 29.9 wt.%) was observed at a temperature range of 100 °C −120 °C due to the loss of moisture and surface water molecules (Fig. 4 ). The second weight loss (29.7 wt.%) was at a temperature range of 340 °C - 370 °C due to degradation of the polymeric form of acetylacetonate and acetate. The third weight loss of about 9.6 wt.% at 390 °C - 400 °C was due to the loss of surface hydroxyl groups of metal surface sites. It is noted that the Mg-Ni-AA composite showed a slight decrease in the weight loss at the temperatures higher than 400 °C due to the formation of oxide forms of the materials. TGA results in Fig. 4 revealed highly thermal stability of the materials. In the case of bimetallic composites, they were stable up to 700 °C without loss of carbide nature. There was no significant amorphous carbon decomposition at above 450 °C. The bimetallic catalyst exhibited the weight loss occurred as shown in Fig. 4. Among the three materials, MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst had a weight loss of 4% of carbon at 670 °C due to a highly stable carbide form as compared to other bimetallic composites such as MgO/Ni3C (1:2 and 2:1). 3.5 XPS analysis The XPS survey spectrum of MgO/Ni3C indicated the presence of Mg, Ni, C, and O elements. This result supported XRD results. Fig. 5 a showed the symmetric peaks at 853.6 eV and 860.1 eV, which were the binding energies of Ni 2p3/2 [42]. The second set of binding energy was located at 871.8 eV and 878.8 eV, corresponding to Ni 2p in Ni 2p1/2. These Ni 2p peaks confirmed that Ni3C with its respective binding energies were well-matched with the previous reports, as shown in Fig. 5b. The XPS spectrum of MgO showed a unique peak at 87.8 eV, which was assigned to Mg 2 s in MgO, as shown in Fig. 5c [43]. The Mg had no carbon peaks Mg-C, which supported the XRD results. The O1s peak observed at 529.6 eV belonged to lattice oxygen at low concentration, as shown in Fig. 5d. The second O1s peak observed at 531.3 eV was due to the carbide group in Ni3C materials. The XPS spectrum of C1s showed a peak at 283.2 eV, which was assigned to C 1 s of the Ni-C bond, as shown in Fig. 5e. This result revealed the high crystallinity of the Ni3C phase, which is consistent with the XRD results. Furthermore, the second C 1 s peak appeared at 288.3 eV indicated the low concentration of amorphous carbon in Ni3C. Interestingly, the percentage of crystalline carbon and amorphous ones in MgO/Ni3C samples was 95% and 5%, respectively. These XPS results and their binding energies confirmed the formation of MgO/Ni3C materials. 3.6 Surface morphology and chemical composition The topography and elemental mapping of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) material were analyzed by SEM coupled with EDX and elemental mapping techniques [34]. Fig. 6 a showed the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst as rod-like morphologies and spherical nature appeared with different lengths and sizes. The rod size was measured at an average of 100 nm, as shown in Fig. 6a. Furthermore, the EDX spectrum of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) result revealed that Ni, Mg, O, and C with different atomic percentages were displayed in Fig. 6b. This result also suggested the same chemical composition of the MgO/Ni3C material as the XPS study. The composite was prepared by a one-step solid-state synthesis with the elemental composition shown in Fig. 5a and 6b. Carbon, mostly nickel carbide, accounted for 5.57% of the total element composition. Another attractive result was found in the similar metal ratios of Ni and Mg in which Mg existed in a high percentage of oxide form. This result also supported the XRD results. Furthermore, the elemental mapping images displayed the different elements such as Ni, Mg, C, and O uniformly distributed over the material surface, as shown in Fig. 6c-f. 4 Optimization of reaction parameter and catalytic activity 4.1 Possible reaction pathways The product distribution and reaction pathways of glycerol conversion into 1,2-propanediol on MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst were shown in Scheme 3. Ni3C acted as an acid site, while MgO acted as a basic site as well as a promoter for reactant carriers. The combination of acidic and basic sites of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst played an essential role in its synergistic effect and catalytic activity. The presence of acid sites in Ni3C has favored the dehydration route via protonation of glycerol and loss of a water molecule to form a ketone group as an intermediate. If a primary OH group was protonated, hydroxyacetone would be formed, which would lead to the formation of 1,2-PDO. Moreover, the hydroxyacetone was thermodynamically less stable at 220 °C and converted into 1,2-propanediol [44]. Ni3C was an effective CC bond cleavage and, therefore, demethylation could lead to the formation of ethylene diols (ethylene glycol and methanol). MgO basic sites were adsorbed onto the hydroxide groups of the reactant molecules. Then, the effective CC bond cleavage of Ni3C facilitated the production of ethylene glycol and hydrogen gas. This in-situ hydrogen over Ni and Mg surface active sites could react with the secondary hydroxyl groups of ethylene glycol to form ethanol. Ethylene diol further underwent CC bond cleavage to form products such as methanol, ethanol, ethane, methane, as well as trace amounts of formic acid, formaldehyde, CO2, CO and so on [14]. Subsequent hydrogenation of the dehydrated intermediates on the metal catalysts resulted in 1,2-PDO. We have noticed that no cyclic products were detected. Under the experimental reaction conditions, the liquid and gas products of glycerol hydrogenolysis were observed, as shown in Scheme 3. The glycerol dehydration into hydroxyacetone on the MgO basic sites at low temperature revealed the high selectivity of hydroxyacetone, as shown in Fig. 8. In gas-phase reactions produced over the surface (acidic and basic), major products were gasses such as CO, CO2 and H2. These internal gasses were further reactive with gas-phase reactions through long reaction time to form CH4, acetaldehyde, formic acid, and other traces gasses. We have proposed the reaction mechanisms of glycerol conversion via two different pathways: liquid and gas. After the catalytic reaction, products were separated into liquid and gas. However, the liquid products were analyzed by a GC/FID to know about the conversion yield and selectivity based on the reference sample. At the same time, gas products were collected and analyzed by a GC/FID and GC/TCD. The GC/FID was used for light hydrocarbons such as methane, ethane, and propane, while GC/TCD was used for other gasses such as H2, CO, and CO2. Based on the gas fractions, the gas composition (%) was calculated and shown in Table 3. Over these gas products, less than 10% contributed to the overall reaction under all reaction conditions. We concluded that the glycerol conversion mechanism had been proposed based on the collected data and results. The available results in literature also support this proposed mechanism of two different phases. 4.2 Effects of reaction temperature Effects of reaction temperature on glycerol conversion at 180 °C - 240 °C using MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO, and Ni3C catalysts were tested using a 100 mL autoclave. Fig. 7 showed the glycerol conversion at 180 °C using different catalysts such as MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), MgO, and Ni3C, which was found to be 45%, 40%, 42%, 18%, and 22%, respectively. The catalytic activity was compared in terms of glycerol conversion, 1, 2 propanediol and hydroxy acetone selectivity, TON, and SRR as shown in Table 2 . Low glycerol conversion was noticed due to insufficient temperature to activate the reactant molecules and surface-active sites. Furthermore, the glycerol conversion of those catalysts gradually rose to 60%, 48%, 50%, 23%, and 28%, respectively, as increasing reaction temperature to 200 °C. The glycerol conversion of MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), MgO, and Ni3C catalysts at 220 °C was found to be increased to 74%, 55%, 58%, 27%, and 34%, respectively. However, by increasing the temperature to 240 °C, there was no increase in the glycerol conversion, as shown in Fig. 7. The glycerol conversion did not show higher values at the increased reaction temperature. The glycerol conversion was lower for mono metal catalysts (Mg and Ni) than for bimetal catalysts. The reaction temperature was optimized at 220 °C. Beyond this temperature, no conversion was further noticed. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the catalytic activities of MgO, Ni3C, MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO/Ni3C (2:1) were compared to each other in terms of SRR and TOF, which was found to be 5.03×10−3 mol g−1 s−1, 8.14×10−3 mol g−1 s−1, 15.03×10−3 mol g−1 s−1, 10.72×10−3 mol g−1 s−1, 11.49×10−3 mol g−1 s−1, respectively (Table 2). Among the above catalysts, MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst reached the maximum conversion of 74% at 220 °C as compared to MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), MgO, and Ni3C catalysts under the same reaction condition, as shown in Fig. 7. The synthesized catalysts in this study were comparable to other catalysts in terms of glycerol conversion, 1,2 propanediol and hydroxyacetone selectivity, SRR and TOF values (Table 2). 4.3 Comparative catalytic activity The comparative catalytic activity at the optimized reaction condition was studied for glycerol conversion on the catalysts as follows: MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), MgO, and Ni3C catalysts as shown in Fig. 8 . The catalytic activity of the catalysts was evaluated by comparing their glycerol conversion with their selectivity (ethylene glycol, 1, 2-propanediol, hydroxyacetone, and others). As shown in Fig. 8, the Ni3C catalyst showed the highest selectivity of 1,2-propanediol, about 67% but low glycerol conversion of 34%. Furthermore, the 1,2-propanediol selectivity was higher than that of other products such as ethylene glycol, hydroxyacetone, and others due to the great acid sites of the Ni3C catalyst. In contrast, the MgO catalyst exhibited the highest hydroxyacetone selectivity of 82% but a low glycerol conversion of 21% due to the dehydration nature of the material. The low glycerol conversion of these mono-metals was due to low molecular (reactant) adsorption and desorption on the surface sites of MgO and Ni3C catalyst. As mentioned above, the glycerol conversion of MgO/Ni3C (1:1), MgO/Ni3C (1:2), MgO/Ni3C (2:1), MgO, and Ni3C determined under the optimized reaction conditions were found to be 74%, 54%, 58%, 27%, and 34%, respectively. Among the catalysts, MgO/Ni3C (1:1) exhibited the highest conversion as compared to other mono and bimetallic catalysts, as shown in Fig. 8. Interestingly, the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a glycerol conversion of 74% and high selectivity of 1, 2-propanediol of 67%. The high conversion and selectivity were noticed for MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalysts due to its acidic and basic nature of active surface sites and the fact that its synergistic nature played an essential role in its catalytic activity. 4.4 Gas composition analysis The gas composition of glycerol conversion using MgO, Ni3C, and MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalysts was examined, and the obtained gas composition was displayed in Table 3 . A significant amount of gasses such as H2, CO & CO2, methane, ethane, and propane were detected during the catalytic reaction [14,24]. The CO2 production of glycerol hydrolysis on different catalysts such as Ni3C, MgO, and MgO/Ni3C (1:1) was 44.9%, 36.14% and 31.1%, respectively. However, the gas composition revealed that the mono metals produced higher amount of CO2 gas which could not be further utilized by the reaction for hydrocarbon formation. MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a minimum H2 production. Its CO2 and CO composition were decreased, whereas its hydrocarbon gasses were gradually increased noticeably. The aqueous phase reaction of the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions led to a high level of hydrocarbon gas products. 4.5 Effects of reaction variates using a superior catalyst 1, 2-propanediol production from glycerol was examined over different loads of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst (25 to 125 mg) under reaction conditions (220 °C, 4 h, 10 wt.% of glycerol and 600 rpm) as shown in Fig. 9 a. The glycerol conversion without the catalyst at 220 °C was less than 10% under the same reaction conditions. As 25 mg of the catalyst was used, the glycerol conversion was about 41%, with high hydroxyacetone selectivity of 72%. Increasing up to 50 g of the catalyst, the glycerol conversion was about 54%, while the selectivity of 1,2-propanediol and hydroxyacetone was 22% and 59%, respectively. The selectivity of 1,2-propanediol was slightly increased at this stage. Further increasing up to 100 mg of the catalyst, the glycerol conversion rose to 74%, the 1,2-propanediol selectivity to 67%, while the hydroxyacetone selectivity declined to 12%. The catalytic system seemed to reach the equilibrium or saturation at higher amounts of the loading catalyst. An increase in the quantity of the catalyst increased the viscosity of the solution, which limited the mass transfer of the reaction, thus, decreasing the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Furthermore, the excess catalyst enriched the surface acid sites and enhanced the side product selectivity, while minimizing 1,2-propanediol. Hence, the catalyst loading was optimized at 100 mg under the assayed reaction conditions. Effects of reaction time on the glycerol conversion and selectivity of desirable products were investigated on MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst at a given reaction condition (220 °C, 0.1 g of catalyst, 4 h, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). As shown in Fig. 9b, the conversion was 54%, while the 1, 2-propanediol selectivity was 29%, and the reaction yielded 13% after 1 h of reaction. As increasing the reaction time up to 4 h, both glycerol conversion, 1, 2-propanediol selectivity and the yield were increased up to 74%, 67% and 42%, respectively. It should be noted that there was no change in the glycerol conversion after 4 - 5 h of reaction. However, the 1, 2-propanediol selectivity and yield were decreased with increasing the side products of gas phase or liquid phase or both. This study concluded that 4 h of reaction was an optimal reaction time. The selectivity was decreased with excess reaction time because surface acid sites and reaction temperature favoured the formation of side products, as shown in Fig. 9b. Catalyst stability was checked using a superior MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst for glycerol conversion under the reaction conditions (220 °C, 4 h, 0.1 g of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol and 600 rpm), and the results were shown in Fig. 9c. Two different calcined and uncalcined catalysts were used for 6 cycles of regeneration. The catalytic reaction after each experimental run followed two different patterns which were washed & calcined and unwashed & uncalcined. After the reaction, the catalyst was washed with solvents (hexane and acetone) and dried overnight, followed by a calcination at 400 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere for 3 h. The obtained material was utilized for the next tests or runs. In contrast, the unwashed and uncalcined catalyst was performed without any further treatment and be ready for the next runs. The calcined and uncalcined catalyst in the first cycle showed 74% and 63% of glycerol conversion, respectively. In the second run, the glycerol conversion was about 69% for the calcined catalyst and 58% for the uncalcined catalyst. These results revealed that the calcined catalyst was more active due to the presence of many active sites. The residual reactants may block the surface of the uncalcined material, thus, reducing the catalyst activity or conversion [41]. It is also true for other 5th and 6th experimental runs in which the glycerol conversion gradually decreased up to 59% (or 48%) and 55% (or 46%) for calcined catalyst (or uncalcined catalyst), respectively. It is noticed that even after the 6th cycle, the glycerol conversion was also reasonable [44], although a slight drop in the conversion was observed, probably due to a small amount of metal leaching due to excessive washing of catalysts. 4.6 Mass balance of product distributions The mass balance of products such as liquid, gas, and char was calculated under the reaction conditions (220 °C, 4 h, 0.1 g of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm) and was shown in Fig. 10 [49]. The mass balance of glycerol conversion without catalytic reaction was 95% for total recovery (liquid and gas) and 5% for char. In the presence of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst, the calculated total recovery (liquid and gas) and char were 96% and 4%, respectively. In the presence of MgO or Ni3C, the total recovery was determined as 90% for MgO & 94% for Ni3C, and the recovery of char was 10% for MgO & 6% for Ni3C. The results suggest the formation of more cracking or gas products and char in the presence of MgO/Ni3C (1:1). Obviously, MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalysts reached a high recovery rate of liquid products as compared to MgO and Ni3C catalysts. 4.7 Spent catalyst characterizations Fig. 11 a showed the morphology of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst which existed as rod-like and spherical structures with different lengths and sizes. The rods had an average size of up to 100 nm, as clearly seen in Fig. 11a. The TEM image of the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) spent catalyst was taken after the 6th run of the catalytic reaction. It is clearly shown that the rods were converted into spherical structures, as shown in Fig. 11b. The catalytic activity and stability of MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst were examined using TGA as shown in Fig 11c. Two different weight losses were observed in the TGA spectra. The first one (about 24.3%) occurred in the temperature range of 100 ºC to 250 ºC due to the loss of surface water and unreacted glycerol over the catalyst surface. The second one (about 13.56%) occurred in the temperature range of 400 ºC to 750 ºC due to the slow decomposition of carbon residues in the O2 atmosphere. It included carbide decomposition at Ni3C catalyst surface at high temperature in the O2 atmosphere. Furthermore, the XRD pattern of the used MgO/Ni3C catalyst (Fig 11d) indicated that its crystallinity and phase purity, as compared to the fresh catalyst, were retained after the regeneration. This XRD result indicated that MgO/Ni3C catalyst exhibited superior activity and long-term stability. The carbon nature of the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) spent catalyst was further confirmed by Raman spectra. Fig. 11e displayed two Raman peaks recorded in the range of 100 cm−1 −1800 cm−1. They were well-matched with the D and G bands of the carbide nature of the material reported elsewhere [50]. The D band at 1320 cm−1 was attributed to the carbon in sp2 hybridization, while the G band at 1580 cm−1 was attributed to the carbide [41]. The G band and D band ratios (ID/IG) demonstrated the degree of graphitic carbon in MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst. The Raman peak intensity of these two bands was not the same. This result was evidenced by the value of ID/IG of 1.24, which suggests that more sp2 domains were formed, indicating that the defect in the Ni3C phase formation depends only on the growth of 2D material. The D and G band (ID/IG) ratio demonstrated the degree of carbide in MgO/Ni3C (1:1) material. 4.8 Comparative catalyst activity For comparison, the available works in literature were tabulated in Table 4 . An outstanding performance towards a maximum selectivity of 1,2-propanediol was recognized for all reported materials. Reported results of the glycerol conversion were compared to those in our study. In this study, no external hydrogen sources were used. Although our materials possessed less glycerol conversion, they exhibited a higher selectivity of 1, 2-propanediol due to the acidity and surface-active sites of MgO/Ni3C catalyst without using any external hydrogen sources for the catalysis. The presence of hydrogen sources would reduce the 1, 2-propanediol selectivity. The advantages of MgO/Ni3C composite catalysts fabricated by the solid-state thermal synthesis can be expressed as follows. These prepared materials exhibited thermal and chemical stability after several cycles of regeneration. Particularly, MgO catalytic system possessed basicity, while Ni3C catalytic system had acidic sites, which enhanced and favored Ni dispersion with minimized coke/carbon deposition under all reaction conditions. MgO facilitated the adsorption of hydroxyl groups of reactant molecules to transport to or promote the surface-active sites of Ni3C, which resulted in highly selective 1,2-propanediol. Active Ni3C phase was well-known for its hydrogen spillover nature and hydrogen production, which enhanced the selective dehydration and CC bond cleavage of reactant glycerol. The selective adsorption of hydroxyl bonding was more feasible on MgO basic sites. 5 Conclusions The MgO, Ni3C and MgO/Ni3C catalysts were successfully synthesized via a one-step solid-state thermal method to produce 1,2-propanediol from glycerol (a by-product of the biodiesel industry) without using any external hydrogen sources. The XRD study confirmed the crystallinity and purity of MgO, Ni3C, and MgO/Ni3C catalysts. The pyridine adsorbed FT-IR results revealed the acidity of the materials. The TGA study confirmed the materials' thermal stability with a weight loss of less than 20%, and their stability up to 700 °C. The materials' surface morphology and element chemical composition were studied by SEM, XPS, EDAX, and elemental mapping of materials. Ni, Mg, O, and C were the unique elements in the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst. Among various catalysts, the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst played an essential role in the catalytic conversion of glycerol to 1, 2-propanediol. This study suggested a maximum glycerol conversion of > 74% and 1,2-propanediol selectivity of 67% for MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalysts. Mass balance of glycerol conversion on MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst was used to calculate the total recovery of liquid and gas or char, which were 96% or 4%, respectively. The MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a minimum H2 production. The other unstable CO gas must be utilized to fine chemical production for refinery reactions. The reusability of the catalyst was proved by 6th cycle of regeneration for the conversion. This study claimed that MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst could be a potential candidate for glycerol conversion and an environmentally benign catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the fabrication of MgO, Ni3C and MgO/Ni3C (1:1, 1:2, & 2:1) catalysts via a one-step solid-state synthesis and the production of 1, 2-propanediol from glycerol (a by-product of the biodiesel industry) on the synthesized catalysts without using any external hydrogen sources were presented. Different physicochemical techniques were used to analyze the synthesized catalysts. The XRD result revealed formation of the composites with MgO/Ni3C pure phase catalyst; 5% amorphous and 95% crystalline nature. The MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a high surface area and pore volume of about 183 m2 g −1 and 0.18 cm3 g −1, respectively. MgO/Ni3C (1:1) showed a superior thermal stability and has a stable regeneration. Catalytic conversion of glycerol to 1, 2-propanediol was investigated under different reaction conditions (180 °C -240 °C, 1–5 h, 25–125 mg of catalyst, 10 wt.% of glycerol, and 600 rpm). Compared to other prepared materials, the MgO/Ni3C (1:1) catalyst showed a superior activity with about 74% of glycerol conversion, 67% of 1, 2-propanediol selectivity, and about 94% of the total product recovery. Its SRR and TOF values were determined as 15.03×10−3 mol g−1 s−1 and 3.01 s−1, respectively. The results demonstrated that MgO/Ni3C (1:1) is a potential candidate for a superior glycerol conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1, 2-propanediol on MgO/Ni3C catalysts fabricated by a solid-state thermal synthesis
